case_title: COMMISSIONER INLAND REVENUE, LEGAL DIV. RTO, HYDERABAD vs Messrs SHAD & CO. CARRIAGE CONTRACTOR HEAD OFFICE, HYDERABAD
appellant: Commissioner Inland Revenue, Legal Division, RTO, Hyderabad
respondant: Messrs SHAD & CO. Carriage Contractor Head Office, Hyderabad

accussed_details.name: N/A
allegation: Failure to maintain books of accounts
Non-compliance with banking channel requirements for transactions

complaint_summary: The appellant contested the order of CIR(A), Hyderabad, which annulled the Taxation Officer's amendments under sections 122(4)(5)/177(6) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001, citing procedural and substantive errors.
investigation_summary: Audit proceedings were initiated under section 177(4) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001, based on discrepancies in income declarations, inflated expenses, and missing documentation. Revised returns were filed but not properly considered.
judgment_summary: The tribunal accepted the appeal, ruling that the Taxation Officer erred by not considering revised returns as per section 122(3) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001. The assessment was declared illegal and canceled.
legal_arguments: Failure to consider revised returns under section 122(3) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 2001.
Procedural lapses in issuing deficiency notices and confronting grounds for audit.

maxims.Legal Maxim: Tax authorities cannot refuse to accept a revised return under any circumstances.

legal_terms.Audit: Examination of financial records to ensure compliance with tax laws.
legal_terms.Revised Return: Amended tax return submitted to correct errors or omissions.

words_and_phrases.Ab Initio: From the beginning; invalid from the outset.
words_and_phrases.Deemed Order: An order considered valid under statutory provisions without explicit issuance.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around procedural and substantive errors in tax audit and assessment. Revised returns were ignored, leading to cancellation of the assessment. Jurisdictional and procedural lapses were highlighted.
